title.narrative: Agricultural Sector Productivity - Agribusiness and Producer Organizations

description.narrative: Agricultural Sector Productivity - Support the growth of small and medium agro-enterprises, including producer organizations/associations, which are engaged in producing, marketing, or adding value (e.g. processing and quality enhancement) to crop, livestock, forestry, and fishery products. Support addresses the needs and capacities of both men and women producers and includes such areas as adoption of technology and technical processes, businesses and human resources management, environmental regulatory compliance, and organizational governance.

person-name.narrative: Tiffany Harris, Country Desk Officer Sri Lanka/Maldives

title.narrative: Private Sector Productivity - Sector Supply and Value Chains

description.narrative: Private Sector Productivity - Enhance the capacity of business, industry trade associations, universities, institutes and local government to develop strategies collectively to create supply and value chains for products and services that will compete nationally and internationally; facilitate linkages among all components of chain members; and provide training and capacity building among male and female personnel within academic faculty, trade associations, and business centers so they will be able to guide further development of supply and value chains.

person-name.narrative: Tiffany Harris, Country Desk Officer Sri Lanka/Maldives

description.narrative: Workforce Development - Create and sustain pre-employment and employability programs for male and female youth and men and women in formal and non-formal settings. These programs develop foundational (pre-requisite or threshold) skills that are adaptable and necessary for entrance into the labor force, vocational training programs, and career-oriented higher education; skills such as critical thinking, teamwork, and communication. Workforce readiness programs may target out-of-school and marginalized youth and adults, or students in general education systems. Programs include labor market and social support services, and linkages with further technical skills development and career opportunities for both young men and women.

person-name.narrative: Tiffany Harris, Country Desk Officer Sri Lanka/Maldives

title.narrative: Elections and Political Processes - Observation, Monitoring and Oversight

description.narrative: Elections and Political Processes - Observation, monitoring, and external oversight by local and international organizations including the use of parallel vote tabulations, quick counts, exit polling, media monitoring, and other related oversight tools.

title.narrative: Program Design and Learning - Program Design and Learning

description.narrative: Program Design and Learning - Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded operating unit wide programs, not for a specific functional objective. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, public outreach, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Funding for similar activities that are directed to specific functional objectives should be entered in the PD&L sub-element of the appropriate program area(s) within that objective.

Rule of Law and Human Rights

description.narrative: USAIDs Connecting Regional Economies (CORE) program helped increase social and economic security in Sri Lankas Eastern Province by stimulating participation in competitive agricultural value chains, creating new livelihood options for vulnerable populations, and promoting workforce development and a pro-business policy environment. CORE acted as a connector between farm and non-farm enterprises, and fast-growing domestic and export markets. Over 12,500 people benefited from CORE activities. Surveys indicated that household incomes rose from 10 to 50 percent as a result of this program.

Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

person-name.narrative: Tiffany Harris, Country Desk Officer Sri Lanka/Maldives

title.narrative: Law Enforcement Restructuring, Reform and Operations - Civilian Police Reform

description.narrative: Law Enforcement Restructuring, Reform and Operations - Develop police forces through capacity-building (training and education both in the classroom and in the field); organizational development; civil service reform (pay and rank reform); management and leadership; equipping, infrastructure, aviation, gender sensitivity, and public affairs, among other activities. As the foundation for such a service is fundamentally rooted in the rule of law and respect for human rights, activities conducted in support of this sub-element should be coordinated with programs under the Rule of Law elements in GJD.

title.narrative: Increased Demand and Engagement for Accountability (IDEA)

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): |Civil society advocacy plays an important role in advancing good governance reforms, as seen clearly in Sri Lanka in 2022. Through the Increased Demand and Engagement for Accountability (IDEA) activity, USAID supports an improved enabling environment for civil society, and strengthens the organizational capacity and sustainability of civil society organizations (CSOs).With FY 2022 resources, USAID will fully obligate the mortgage of IDEA activity. With FY 22 resources, USAID will continue to provide post-award administration, management, and capacity building for three sister USAID awards to local Sri Lankan CSOs. This activity will also conduct an organizational capacity assessment to develop a capacity building program for participating CSOs to meet standardized USAID mission requirements and build their capacity to directly manage USAID funds after IDEA ends.FY2022 resources will also strengthen the enabling environment for civil society in Sri Lanka and will prepare scenarios to safeguard CSO operational space and prevent backsliding.Through this activity, USAID advances the US Embassy Integrated Country Strategy Mission Objective 2.3: 'Bolster civil society and free and independent media' and the Country Development Cooperation Strategy Development Objective 1: 'Effective Democratic Governance Strengthened'.$847,000 within this IM will contribute to the required DRG directive of $15,100,000, and $50,000 within this IM contributes to the TIP earmark of $350,000.. .. ... .

description.narrative: Support and strengthen the negotiation process and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

title.narrative: Partnership for Accelerating Results in Trade, National Expenditure, and Revenue activity

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): Sri Lanka is experiencing economic headwinds resulting from long standing economic governance setbacks, cycles of protectionist policies and economic regression exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic. USAID/Sri Lanka's Partnership for Accelerating Results in Trade, National Expenditure, and Revenue activity (PARTNER) is a ready instrument to mobilize relevant technical assistance in support of the proposed economic reforms.Through the mobilization of public revenue, the improvement of public sector procurement functions, and the improvement of public sector auditing, PARTNER activity will improve government efficiency and service delivery. Through this activity, USAID will also improve government capacity to improve the business enabling environment and the private sector capacity to import and export goods.With FY2022 funds, USAID will continue to provide technical assistance through long-term and short-term technical experts. Through this activity, USAID will strengthen public financial management practices to support the government's macro fiscal reforms required to obtain International Monetary Fund financial support. USAID will fund technical assistance to strengthen the capacity of public sector accounting and auditing professionals to implement the Sri Lanka Public Sector Accounting Standards. With FY 2022 funds, USAID will continue providing technical assistance to micro, small and medium enterprises, particularly in tourism and export industries, and to women-owned and-managed businesses to overcome barriers to trade.This activity advances the US Embassy Sri Lanka Integrated Country Strategy Mission Objective 3.1: 'Foster Sustainable Economic Growth.' and the Country Development Cooperation Strategy Development Objective 2: 'Inclusive Market-Driven Growth Increased'.$2,978,914 within this IM contributes to the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise directive of $5,700,000.

For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): The majority of Sri Lankan firms only conduct business within sub-national regions of the country and do not consider participating in international trade, limiting their potential for growth. This pattern is especially common for firms classified as small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which account for half of national GDP. Furthermore, Sri Lankan SMEs experience stagnant growth due to various constraints, including but not limited to, lack of access to business development services and capital; regulatory constraints; and weak market linkages..Sri Lanka @ 100 will select mid-market firms with high growth potential from the SME spectrum to scale their businesses, helping them expand into regional and global markets. It will provide technical assistance (TA) to selected mid-market firms to attract more investment, improve profitability, and increase productivity. It will support businesses to improve their internal operational capabilities, facilitate access to new markets, position mid-market companies for smart capital, and improve access to business advisory services. TA will include management consultancy services, tax and audit support, financial accounting, legal and intellectual property protection, and other related support..This activity advances private sector competitiveness in Sri Lanka and supports Integrated Country Strategy Mission Objective 3.1, sustained and inclusive economic growth. The objectives of the activity also fall within the Development Objective 2 (Inclusive Market-Driven Growth increased) and Intermediate Result 2.2 (Private Sector Led Growth Promoted) of Sri Lanka's Country Development Cooperation Strategy. .$1.35 million within this IM contributes to the Micro-, Small-, and Medium- Enterprise directive of $2.7 million......

(Sri Lanka): The 2022 protests in Sri Lanka highlighted the urgency that Sri Lankans place on political reform and the importance of parliamentary oversight functions. Through the Inclusive Participatory Process (IPP) activity, USAID will build the capacity of the parliament of Sri Lanka and multi-political parties and civil society organizations to improve the political and civic participation of women, youth, and under-represented groups. IPP will also provide technical support to the Election Commission (EC) to safeguard transparent and inclusive electoral processes.With FY 2022 funding, IPP will assist the EC in developing civic and voter education material and carrying out voter awareness campaigns. Through IPP, USAID will train 25 youth and 75 women representing multiple political parties and civic groups on political and civic participation. Should elections be declared, IPP will also award two subgrants to local organizations to conduct short-term and long-term election observation missions for the local and parliamentary elections.Through this activity, USAID advances the US Embassy's Integrated Country Strategy Mission Objective 2.2: 'Build support for adherence to rule-of-law, transparency, and inclusive governance' and the USAID Country Development Cooperation Strategy Development Objective 1: 'Effective Democratic Governance Strengthened.'$2,000,000 within this IM will contribute to the required DRG directive of $15,100,000.

description.narrative: Build the capacity of the private sector, civil society, and government to respond and adapt to climate change in ways that contribute to sustained, inclusive, market-based growth. It will help identify and scale up innovative solutions to climate-related challenges, strengthen governance to address climate-related risks, and improve access to high-quality information for decision-making to reduce vulnerability to climate change.

(Sri Lanka): Sri Lanka's justice system faces a significant challenge with case delays, with some cases taking decades to resolve, delaying the execution of justice. USAID's Efficient and Effective Justice (EEJ) activity strengthens the justice system by introducing international best practices and improving systems, procedures and the capacity of justice sector actors.With FY 2022 funding, USAID will work closely with the Ministry of Justice and Judicial Service Commission to improve case management systems in courts, as well as improve capacity of judicial and non-judicial personnel in courts and other justice sector institutions, court management systems, and information sharing and user feedback mechanisms.In addition, USAID will support the Bar Association of Sri Lanka, other lawyer associations, and justice sector institutions, such as the Judges' Training Institution and Attorney General's Department, to adopt and implement standardized programs for continuing legal education, continuing judicial education, and capacity building of non-judicial personnel. Further, USAID will work with the private sector to introduce and promote Alternative Dispute Resolution mechanisms.USAID will support improving legal education as a long term means of improving the justice sector through producing more skilled legal professionals. For this purpose, USAID will work with law schools to adopt new curricular and teaching methods.Aligning with the US Embassy's Integrated Country Strategy Mission Objective 2.2: 'Build support for adherence to rule-of-law, transparency, and inclusive governance.' This activity also supports the USAID Country Development Cooperation Strategy Development Objective 1: 'Effective Democratic Governance Strengthened.'$2,650,000 funding within this IM contributes to the required DRG directive of $15,100,000.

title.narrative: Empowering CSOs to Combat Human Trafficking in Sri Lanka (SL)

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): Through the Empowering Civil Society Organizations to Combat Human Trafficking in Sri Lanka (ECCT) activity, USAID strengthens civil society at national and district levels to protect the rights of migrants.USAID will use FY2022 resources to strengthen policies and mechanisms to address human trafficking related crimes, identify, protect and refer victims of trafficking and communities at risk, and to encourage safe migration practices among those seeking to migrate. USAID will closely work with government stakeholders at both the national and local level and foster close collaborative links spanning across five provinces in Sri Lanka.Through ECCT activity, USAID will also work with selected civil society organizations (CSO) from the North Central Province of Sri Lanka to train them on issues related to human trafficking so that they may create awareness among their communities and contribute to policy advocacy. The CSOs will be introduced to journalists from the locality so that they may feed into each other's work on human trafficking and work in collaboration to address this issue. Local media will also be invited to provide coverage to trafficking that takes place at the grassroots level.USAID will also train youth on human trafficking to create champions and foster awareness of risk among youth networks. Most youth remain unaware of the dangers of human trafficking despite the surge in foreign employment migration in the country.Through this activity, USAID advances the Integrated Country Strategy Mission Objective 2.3: 'Bolster civil society and free and independent media in their efforts to promote democratic governance and respect for human rights among the Sri Lankan public'. This activity also supports the USAID Country Development Cooperation Strategy Development Objective 1: 'Effective, Democratic Governance Strengthened'.$300,000 within this IM contributes to the TIP earmark of $350,000.. .

description.narrative: The WAV Project promotes national, regional, and local collaboration and networking among government and non-government organizations, allowing them to better implement sustainable interventions that address the needs and protect the human rights of people who have experienced SGBV, thereby advancing gender equality.

(Sri Lanka): As a result of electricity subsidies tariffs and due to a reliance on fossil fuel imports for power generation, Sri Lanka's energy system is inefficient and costly. Through the Sri Lanka Energy activity, USAID will provide technical assistance to the Ministry of Power and Energy, the Public Utilities Commission, the utility, the private sector, and other key sector counterparts to improve sector efficiency and sustainability. The activity has four key objectives: (1) Improve the cost-reflectivity of electricity tariffs (2) Increase the deployment of renewable energy (3) Improve demand side management and (4) Deploy advanced technologies.With FY 2022 funding to support government priorities to improve efficiency, USAID will support energy audits for supermarket chain outlets and financial institutions. In addition, USAID is also looking to pilot demand side management activities at a local-distribution level. To provide assistance to the Government of Sri Lanka to develop charging stations for smaller-scale two- or three- wheeled-vehicles, the activity will also conduct studies on financing mechanisms. This activity will also pilot initiatives that showcase storage solutions to ensure new renewable energy infrastructure is effective and conduct capacity-building for sector stakeholders to introduce new energy storage technologies. USAID continues to support the utility and regulator through the process of developing cost reflective tariffs; the development of an end user tariff model is an ongoing activity.The activity will accelerate sustainable energy independence and grid resilience in line with the Clean EDGE framework. The activity advances the Integrated Country Strategy Mission Objective 3.2: 'Assist Sri Lanka's move toward an equitable and clean energy future'. The activity also supports Country Development Cooperation Strategy Development Objective 3: 'Resilience of resources to shocks and stresses enhanced'.. .

description.narrative: Workforce Development - Create and sustain pre-employment and employability programs for male and female youth and men and women in formal and non-formal settings. These programs develop foundational (pre-requisite or threshold) skills that are adaptable and necessary for entrance into the labor force, vocational training programs, and career-oriented higher education; skills such as critical thinking, teamwork, and communication. Workforce readiness programs may target out-of-school and marginalized youth and adults, or students in general education systems. Programs include labor market and social support services, and linkages with further technical skills development and career opportunities for both young men and women.

sector.narrative: Public sector policy and administrative management

description.narrative: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Supports the following illustrative program-funded costs: salaries of US, FSN, and TCN and other staff such as PSCs, RSSAs, PASAs, CASUs working for the US Government managing, administering, and supporting programs and their program-funded benefits such as housing, travel, transportation, education allowances etc; institutional contractors that provide such staff, rent, IT services, the program-funded share of utilities, staff training costs and the cost of developing and administering training programs, equipment and supplies, ICASS, vehicle fuel and maintenance, maintenance contracts, janitorial services, operational unit web page development and maintenance, outreach such as publications and the cost of their preparation (including staff costs), and technical assistance to ensure USG compliance with regulations.

description.narrative: This project will restore the lives and livelihoods of the returnee population, to strengthen resiliency at the household level and to accelerate the process of durable resettlement in key areas of the Northern Province. Support to livelihoods will form a key component of the program. Traditional cash crops including onions, chillies and vegetables will be produced in order to catalyse household income amongst farmers. Communities will also be assisted to revive fisheries with the restoration of productive asset(boats and nets) of fishing families who form the local fishing cooperatives. The activity will also focus on strengthening sustainable economic opportunities of farming families by focusing on improving the rice market. Farming families affected by lack of proper storage for their paddy will be supported by the activity with the establishment of proper storage facilities and training for improved seed paddy production.

person-name.narrative: Tiffany Harris, Country Desk Officer Sri Lanka/Maldives

description.narrative: (Maldives): The "Maldives Women and Youth" (MWAY) project aims to build on the "Maldives Election Support Activity" project initiated in 2013. Drawing on established relationships with key stakeholders and extensive international experience in conducting similar programs, IFES works with national CSOs and state institutions to provide civic education for young people, promote women's political participation, as well as promote the integrity of electoral and political processes through campaign finance reform.The MWAY program aims to:- Increase knowledge of young women and men, girls and boys, about the core values essential to democratic citizenship- Improve public perception of women in leadership roles- Increase capacity of Maldivian youth and women to overcome barriers to participation in civic life- Increase involvement of Maldives youth and women in community decision making processes- Improve electoral laws and regulations.

title.narrative: Working for Wellbeing: rebuilding and revitalizing communities through sustainable livelihoods

description.narrative: The project is supported under the Development Grants Program. The project will aim to restore the lives and livelihoods of the returnee population, to strengthen resiliency at the household level and to accelerate the resettlement process in key areas of the Northern Province. Livelihoods will be focused on specialised and high value crops (eg. cashew, subsidiary crops); working with local farmer and fisheries associations and building their capacities and working with communities to improve infrastructure such as irrigation, shelters and community buildings. With the re-establishment of sustainable livelihoods, resettled communities will be able to improve their socio-economic conditions and reduce their dependency on donor assistance.

title.narrative: Safe, Disaster-Resilient Drinking Water to Floods and Drought Prone Areas in Sri Lanka (SL)

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): USAID will improve resilience in marginalized Sri Lankan households and communities subject to floods, droughts, or water-related hygiene and disease issues. Although water-rich, Sri Lanka is beset by cycles of droughts and floods, issues around contaminated groundwater, bureaucratic water management and governance structures, and water related disease epidemics. In light of this, USAID/Sri Lanka is conducting a water-related private sector engagement assessment, to examine ways that USAID can structure a new project around strengthening disaster risk reduction efforts through innovative synergies with the private sector. This project has addressed the water needs of disaster susceptible communities, conducted disaster risk/vulnerability assessments, and strengthened response and preparedness. . .Using FY 2021 funds, USAID is planning to strengthen the organizational capacity of Lanka Rainwater Harvesting Forum, the implementing partner of this activity, to meet the needs, priorities, and expectations of their constituents and communities..

title.narrative: Media Empowerment for Democratic Sri Lanka (MEND)

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): USAID's Media Empowerment for a Democratic Sri Lanka (MEND) activity will improve citizens' access to balanced, reliable, and objective news by strengthening the media sector. Since 2014, Sri Lanka's ranking on the World Press Freedom index has improved from 165 to 127 due to reduced threats against media, investigations into unsolved journalist deaths, and the right to information codified in the 19th Constitutional Amendment and implemented by the Right to Information Commission..Despite this progress, issues remain that stymie a professional and free media. MEND activities address these issues by strengthening the media sector, advancing citizen access to reliable and objective news, improving media governance and enabling environment, increasing media capacity to provide balanced, informed, and ethical reporting, and acting as a forum for national dialogue. MEND engages with media sector institutions, professionals, journalists, editors, and state and private commissions and agencies to improve media sector institutions. .Technical assistance will improve journalist professionalism, facilitate cross-ethnic and regional collaboration within the media industry, and improve media literacy among the public. MEND will provide customized support to selected media institutions to improve the quality of production, content, and online capacity through mentorship and training. The activity will also work with the media to foster public dialogue on reconciliation and areas of public interest. MEND will strengthen the demand for accurate and unbiased media reporting by raising public awareness on disinformation and misinformation..Empowering the media contributes to stability in Sri Lanka in line with the Integrated Country Strategy objective 2.2 to empower media capable of serving all Sri Lankans while holding state institutions accountable..

description.narrative: Disarmament, Demobilization & Reintegration (DDR) - Reintegrate belligerents back into their communities, and women and children associated with armed groups, by: supporting infrastructure, quartering and civic training for ex-combatants; providing temporary jobs; funding education and vocational training for ex-combatants and their families; providing funding for income-generation; and offering remedial schooling, trauma counseling and family reintegration. It may also include family tracing and reunification of former child combatants, both boys and girls. Such programs are normally community based, and activities conducted herein should be integrated whenever possible with their sectoral counterparts, e.g. Investing in People/Education or Economic Growth/Economic Opportunity. They should also be connected to the Durable Solutions activities undertaken as part of Humanitarian Assistance.

description.narrative: Improve the ability of the USG, host countries and other partners to prepare for and mitigate the effects of disasters, including both natural disasters and complex emergencies, taking into account the differences in men and womens freedom of movement and access to information. Activities under this component include any efforts to enhance the capacities of the USG (in Washington and in the field), humanitarian assistance providers, national host-country authorities, and local communities to engage in disaster reduction and response activities. Activities consist of standardized and coordinated assessments, monitoring, information sharing, data and situational analysis, joint planning; enhancement of coping mechanisms, including the capacity to address adaptation to constantly changing situations on the ground including climate variability and climate change.

title.narrative: Reefs Generate Environmental and Economic Resiliency for Atoll Ecosystems (REGENERATE)

description.narrative: (Maldives): .The REGENERATE activity supports Maldives to strengthen management of coral reefs and mitigate adverse effects of environmental vulnerabilities, which is vital in a country heavily reliant on tourism dollars and tourists attracted to Maldives stunning coral reefs and beautiful marine environment. Funding supports four objectives: (1) improve access to science and technology for decision making and establish policy frameworks for increasing coastal resilience; (2) increase stakeholder capacity to measure, monitor and adapt to climate stresses through education, training and outreach; (3) strengthen governance in support of decentralized management for more resilient reef ecosystems; and (4) establish sustainable financing mechanisms to support climate-resilient marine management. This activity contributes to the economy and security pillars under USAID's strategy to advance the Indo-Pacific Vision. ..REGENERATE, implemented by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), draws on the expertise of an organization internationally recognized for working with governments to mitigate the risks and effects of environmental vulnerabilities. Through IUCN's technical expertise, REGENERATE supports the Maldivian Government's vision for selected regions in the country to be nominated as a United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Biosphere Reserves. FY 2019 resources will be used to fund outreach, training and technical assistance to conduct key interventions such as collecting ecological data; raising awareness and local ownership of natural resources; and conducting stakeholder consultations with the public and private sector. These interventions will inform the technical application submitted to UNESCO and support stakeholder buy-in. REGENERATE contributes to Mission Objective 2.2, to improve Maldives natural resource management to promote long term sustainable development and economic growth... .

title.narrative: Promoting accountability and reconciliation in Sri Lanka Program

description.narrative: The election of the new President of Sri Lanka in January 2015 and the Parliament in August 2015 has created a significant opening of space for Office of High Commissioner of Human Rights (OHCHR)'s work in-country, particularly on transitional justice issues. The comprehensive OHCHR report on Sri Lanka is tabled for discussion at the HRC on 30 September.The contribution to OHCHR will support~OHCHR's human rights monitoring and capacity building activities in Sri Lanka, including:~ translating the OHCHR report investigation on Sri Lanka into Tamil and Singhalese; technical assistance of a human rights advisor to help build and strengthen Sri Lanka's capacity to promote and protect human rights, through~ advising and providing training to independent national human rights institutions and other stakeholders; supporting OHCHR staff to work on transitional justice issues in Sri Lanka.

title.narrative: Support for Professional and Institutional Capacity Enhancement (SPICE)

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): The Support for Professional and Institutional Capacity Enhance (SPICE) program will provide core support and activity sub-grants to key national and regional civil society organizations that promote democratic standards and protect human rights; strengthen the management and institutional capacity of civil society organizations; and support civil society led initiatives to support democracy and governance objectives in Sri Lanka. Four components support this project purpose of "increased and more inclusive citizen participation in development and governance" and would focus on protecting citizens' rights; supporting citizen participation and national dialogue around pluralism, inclusion and reconciliation; enhancing the management and technical capacity of civil society organization's; and ensuring that critical Democracy, Human Rights and Governance (DRG) advocacy and rights organizations are sustained.

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): .The Improved Election Management Program supports free and fair electoral processes by building the institutional capacity of the Election Commission of Sri Lanka . The recent constitutional crisis puts Provincial, Parliamentary and Presidential elections on unpredictable timelines.. The electoral system is vulnerable to foreign influence and vote-buying, due to the lack of legal infrastructure on these issues, and attacks on voter information due to poorly protected data management systems. FY 2018 funds will provide technical support and training to help the Election Commission strengthen information integrity, combat disinformation campaigns, respond to election disputes, address campaign finance issues, and strengthen their Right to Information compliance. Targeted activities will support legal reforms on campaign finance, set up on a multi-party operational unit, and improve parliamentary engagement on the Open Government Partnership... ..Also, FY 2018 funds will support local civil society organizations to carry out voter education, voter registration services, election observations, and monitor and report on election violence and the abuse of state resources. Trainings and awareness campaigns will promote the active participation of women as candidates and voters and the engagement of youth in the political process. This comprehensive approach will improve sustainable political reform and democratic gains in Sri Lanka, increase the ability of the government to engage with citizens and strengthen citizens' access to information on the political process and ability to hold government accountable... .This activity helps achieve the ICS objective to strengthen key government institutions to uphold rule of law and good governance and support the Indo-Pacific strategy through transparent and accountable governance that enables a rules-based order....

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): Youth unemployment in Sri Lanka is exacerbated by the mismatches between the skills Sri Lankan employers need and the skills the Sri Lankan labor force has. Through the Youth Employment and Business Start-up activity, "YouLead" USAID works with a wide array of public and private partners to strengthen youth skills development, improve the quality of technical and vocational education and training, and increase prospects for gainful self-employment.USAID will use FY 2022 resources to expand initiatives to increase youth participation in the workforce and as entrepreneurs, and to promote digital learning content to increase youth access to career guidance and training. USAID will continue to increase the number of partnerships with the private sector, taking a demand driven approach to co-creating and implementing employment-linked capacity building initiatives. In addition, USAID will facilitate private-public dialogue and behavioral change outreach programs, develop and validate curricula, and build employment pathways.This activity advances the US Embassy Sri Lanka Integrated Country Strategy's Goal 3.1: 'Foster Sustainable Economic Growth,' the Indo-Pacific Strategy's key pillar 'Drive Indo-Pacific Prosperity' and the USAID Country Development Cooperation Strategy Development Objective 2: 'Inclusive, Market-Driven Growth Increased.'$1,104,649 within this IM contributes to the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise directive of $5,700,000, and $500,000 within this IM contributes to the Higher Education directive of $500,000.

description.narrative: Program to Enhance Climate Resiliency and Water Security (PECRWS)

Improve the capacity and sustainability of civil and criminal justice sector actors and institutions, enhance coordination amongst them, develop citizen demand for an effective and accountable justice system, and develop associations to advocate for all citizens. Justice sector actors and institutions include: police, border security, prosecutors, forensics experts, judges, court personnel, public defenders, corrections personnel, private bar, law schools, legal professional associations, and training institutions for each of them. Work towards an equitable justice system by ensuring equality before the law, fair trial standards, and other elements of procedural fairness. Ensure more equitable access to justice through innovations within and beyond the state system and through improvements in the quality and quantity of justice services, with a particular focus on women, youth, the poor, and other marginalized or vulnerable groups. Programs primarily focused on trafficking in persons or migrant smuggling should be included in element 5.3 under the Transnational Crime area in the Peace and Security Objective.

person-name.narrative: Tiffany Harris, Country Desk Officer Sri Lanka/Maldives

title.narrative: Strengthening Democratic Governance and Accountability (SDGAP) in Sri Lanka

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): .The Strengthening Democratic Governance and Accountability Project (SDGAP) will improve democratic governance, and advance reform and accountability by strengthening Sri Lankan systems and processes. Strong and effective democracies need well-functioning legal frameworks, institutions, systems, and processes to ensure government accountability, enhance transparency, and tackle corruption. Citizen participation and the free flow of information also play a fundamental role in ensuring government accountability and transparency, as well as in furthering government legitimacy and effectiveness. SDGAP contributes towards making these principles of good governance a part of Sri Lanka's political culture... ..Assistance will continue to provide targeted technical and institutional capacity development assistance to the Parliament of Sri Lanka, specifically the oversight committee on Anti-Corruption, Legal reform and Media, Committee of Public Accounts, Committee on Public Enterprise, Public Finance Committee and independent commissions including the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) to promote institutions, processes, and policies that are transparent and accountable across all levels of governance cutting across all development sectors including economic governance. Furthermore, SDGAP will continue supporting targeted civil society organizations that support civic education and advocacy for reform of laws and practices or directly improving accountability and transparency of governance processes at national and sub national levels... .SDGAP supports the ICS objective to strengthen key government institutions to uphold rule of law and good governance; supports the Indo-Pacific Strategy through transparent and accountable governance that enables a rules-based order; and strengthen the country's journey to self-reliance. ..

title.narrative: Supporting Accelerated Investment in Sri Lanka (SAIL)

description.narrative: (Sri Lanka): .The Supporting Accelerated Investment in Sri Lanka (SAIL) activity will support Sri Lanka to: (a) reduce barriers to trade and improve market access, by removing restrictions on foreign ownership and nationality requirements in government procurement and infrastructure projects; (b) lower the cost of doing business, by streamlining procedures for obtaining permits and licenses, and ease labor market restrictions; and (c) promote greater competition by procurement reform, strengthened antitrust and competition requirements, and promoting standards conformity following international best practices... ..With 2018 funds, technical assistance provided will support increasing staff capacity at Ministry of Development Strategies and International Trade (MODSIT) to implement a mechanism to monitor implementation of Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) and the World Trade Organization Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA), revise the Import-Export Control Law, and train staff on FTA international best practices. SAIL will assist the Ministry of Labor to draft a new labor law to address the currently highly fragmented labor regime, which are significant impediments to competitiveness and economic growth in Sri Lanka. SAIL will also work with the Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority and other agencies involved in the business approvals process to streamline approval processes in order to reduce the time it takes to get a new business approved and increase opportunities for foreign direct investment. .. ..SAIL activities support the ICS objective to foster sustained and inclusive economic growth in Sri Lanka, and a free and open Indo-Pacific region in support of the Indo-Pacific Strategy. .. .

title.narrative: Coherent, Open, Responsive and Effective (CORE) Justice Program

description.narrative: This activity will help to strengthen the judicial system by improving its processes and capacities. It will focus assistance primarily on justice sector institutions, including the Ministry of Justice, Attorney Generals Department, the Judicial Services Commission, and the Judges Institute. It will also work with the Bar Association of Sri Lanka and other civil society organizations that are actively involved in justice system reform and rule of law issues.

title.narrative: Reintegration and Stabilization in the East and North (RISEN)

description.narrative: Reintegration and Stabilization in the East and North (RISEN) program implemented a wide range of conflict prevention and mitigation measures to create and promote stability. RISENs goal was to improve personal and economic security in targeted communities in the East, providing support and opportunities for at-risk youth, and building public confidence that core conflict issues are being addressed by the Government of Sri Lanka.

Improve the ability of the USG, host countries and other partners to prepare for and mitigate the effects of disasters, including both natural disasters and complex emergencies, taking into account the differences in men and womens freedom of movement and access to information. Activities under this component include any efforts to enhance the capacities of the USG (in Washington and in the field), humanitarian assistance providers, national host-country authorities, and local communities to engage in disaster reduction and response activities. Activities consist of standardized and coordinated assessments, monitoring, information sharing, data and situational analysis, joint planning; enhancement of coping mechanisms, including the capacity to address adaptation to constantly changing situations on the ground including climate variability and climate change.
